Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Cervical Epidural Analgesia in Head and Neck Cancer Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Thirty patients aged 18-65 years with ASA status I or II undergoing elective head and neck cancer surgery were randomised into two groups

Participants.evidence: Thirty patients aged 18-65 years with ASA status I or II undergoing elective head and neck cancer surgery

Intervention.evidence: Group E (cervical epidural analgesia with general anesthesia) and Group G (general anesthesia alone)

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to evaluate the effect of cervical epidural analgesia on opioid and anesthetic requirements and stress response in head and neck cancer surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the requirement of morphine, isoflurane, and vecuronium, measured intra-operatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was done using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment via sequentially numbered opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not possible due to the nature of the intervention.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Fifteen patients were randomised to each group

Number_Analysed.evidence: with 14 in Group E and 15 in Group G completing the study.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Group E showed a significant reduction in morphine (p < 0.001), isoflurane (p = 0.004), and vecuronium (p = 0.001) requirements.

Harms.evidence: Adverse events included bradycardia in 6.6% and hypotension in 13.3% of Group E.
